summary: Orlando Bosch was a prominent Cuban exile leader involved in anti-Castro activities. The documents reveal his involvement in various events, including the bombing of a Cuban airliner, and his connections to the CIA and Venezuelan government officials. He was under the protection of Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez in late September to mid-October 1976. Bosch faced legal issues, including imprisonment and potential release considerations by the Venezuelan government, and a suspended sentence in 1966. Intelligence reports detail his deteriorating health during a hunger strike and fears of exile reprisals. He is also mentioned in connection with the assassination of Rolando Masferrer and the use of false Chilean identity documents. The documents span from the 1960s to the late 1970s, highlighting Bosch's sustained involvement in anti-Castro activities and his interactions with intelligence agencies and other Cuban exile groups.
significance: The Latin America Division (LAD) report, dated June 29, 1977, summarizes a task force investigation into possible Cuban complicity in the John F. Kennedy assassination, reviewing Agency operations against Cuba from 1960 to 1965 and finding no definitive proof of Cuban involvement.
